If `ξ` is an integer, all its convergents equal `ξ`.

type: ∀ {ξ : ℤ} (n : ℕ), Real.convergent (↑ξ) n = ↑ξ
name: Real.convergent_of_int
docString: If `ξ` is an integer, all its convergents equal `ξ`.

For all natural numbers x, ↑x < ⊤ in the real numbers.

name: PartENat.natCast_lt_top
docString: For all natural numbers x, ↑x < ⊤ in the real numbers.

This theorem states that for any two natural numbers `m` and `n`, `m` divides `n` if and only if the integer representation of `m` divides the integer representation of `n`. Here, `↑m` and `↑n` denote the integer representations of the natural numbers `m` and `n`, respectively. The `∀` symbol denotes universality, meaning that the statement holds for all instances of `m` and `n`. The `∣` symbol represents the divides relation.

type: ∀ {m n : ℕ}, ↑m ∣ ↑n ↔ m ∣ n
name: Int.ofNat_dvd
docString: This theorem states that for any two natural numbers `m` and `n`, `m` divides `n` if and only if the integer representation of `m` divides the integer representation of `n`. Here, `↑m` and `↑n` denote the integer representations of the natural numbers `m` and `n`, respectively. The `∀` symbol denotes universality, meaning that the statement holds for all instances of `m` and `n`. The `∣` symbol represents the divides relation.

For any `y < 1` and any positive `x`, there exists `n : ℕ` with `y ^ n < x`.

type:
∀ {α : Type u_1} [inst : LinearOrderedSemifield α] [inst_1 : Archimedean α] [inst_2 : ExistsAddOfLE α] {x y : α},
  0 < x → y < 1 → ∃ n, y ^ n < x
name: exists_pow_lt_of_lt_one
docString: For any `y < 1` and any positive `x`, there exists `n : ℕ` with `y ^ n < x`.

For every positive number x and y > 1 in a linear ordered Archimedean semifield α, there exists an integer n such that 0 < y^n < x <= y^(n+1).

type:
∀ {α : Type u_1} [inst : LinearOrderedSemifield α] [inst_1 : Archimedean α] [inst_2 : ExistsAddOfLE α] {x y : α},
  0 < x → 1 < y → ∃ n, x ∈ Set.Ioc (y ^ n) (y ^ (n + 1))
name: exists_mem_Ioc_zpow
docString: For every positive number x and y > 1 in a linear ordered Archimedean semifield α, there exists an integer n such that 0 < y^n < x <= y^(n+1).

This theorem states that for any given rational number, denoted as ξ, there exists only a finite set of rational numbers (q) such that the absolute difference between ξ and q is less than one divided by the square of the denominator of q. In other words, the number of "good" rational approximations (those within a certain precision based on the size of their denominator) for any given rational number is finite.

type: ∀ (ξ : ℚ), {q | |ξ - q| < 1 / ↑q.den ^ 2}.Finite
name: Rat.finite_rat_abs_sub_lt_one_div_den_sq
docString: This theorem states that for any given rational number, denoted as ξ, there exists only a finite set of rational numbers (q) such that the absolute difference between ξ and q is less than one divided by the square of the denominator of q. In other words, the number of "good" rational approximations (those within a certain precision based on the size of their denominator) for any given rational number is finite.

The multiplicative indicators of δ-thickenings of a set tend pointwise to the multiplicative
indicator of the set, as δ>0 tends to zero.

type:
∀ {α : Type u_1} [inst : PseudoEMetricSpace α] {β : Type u_2} [inst_1 : One β] [inst_2 : TopologicalSpace β] (f : α → β)
  (E : Set α),
  Filter.Tendsto (fun δ => Set.mulIndicator (Metric.thickening δ E) f) (nhdsWithin 0 (Set.Ioi 0))
    (nhds (Set.mulIndicator (closure E) f))
name: tendsto_mulIndicator_thickening_mulIndicator_closure
docString:
The multiplicative indicators of δ-thickenings of a set tend pointwise to the multiplicative
indicator of the set, as δ>0 tends to zero.

Pointwise, the multiplicative indicators of δ-thickenings of a set eventually coincide
with the multiplicative indicator of the set as δ>0 tends to zero.

type:
∀ {α : Type u_1} [inst : PseudoEMetricSpace α] {β : Type u_2} [inst_1 : One β] (f : α → β) (E : Set α) (x : α),
  ∀ᶠ (δ : ℝ) in nhdsWithin 0 (Set.Ioi 0),
    Set.mulIndicator (Metric.thickening δ E) f x = Set.mulIndicator (closure E) f x
name: mulIndicator_thickening_eventually_eq_mulIndicator_closure
docString:
Pointwise, the multiplicative indicators of δ-thickenings of a set eventually coincide
with the multiplicative indicator of the set as δ>0 tends to zero.

If `z ∈ 𝒟ᵒ`, and `n : ℤ`, then `|z + n| > 1`.

type: ∀ {z : UpperHalfPlane}, z ∈ ModularGroup.fdo → ∀ (n : ℤ), 1 < Complex.normSq ↑(ModularGroup.T ^ n • z)
name: ModularGroup.one_lt_normSq_T_zpow_smul
docString: If `z ∈ 𝒟ᵒ`, and `n : ℤ`, then `|z + n| > 1`.

If `ξ` is rational, then the good rational approximations to `ξ` have bounded
numerator and denominator.

type: ∀ {ξ q : ℚ}, |ξ - q| < 1 / ↑q.den ^ 2 → q.den ≤ ξ.den ∧ ⌈ξ * ↑q.den⌉ - 1 ≤ q.num ∧ q.num ≤ ⌊ξ * ↑q.den⌋ + 1
name: Rat.den_le_and_le_num_le_of_sub_lt_one_div_den_sq
docString:
If `ξ` is rational, then the good rational approximations to `ξ` have bounded
numerator and denominator.

Induction principle for intervals of real numbers: if a proposition `P` is true
on `[x₀, r * x₀)` and if `P` for `[x₀, r^n * x₀)` implies `P` for `[r^n * x₀, r^(n+1) * x₀)`,
then `P` is true for all `x ≥ x₀`.

type:
∀ {P : ℝ → Prop} (x₀ r : ℝ),
  1 < r →
    0 < x₀ →
      (∀ x ∈ Set.Ico x₀ (r * x₀), P x) →
        (∀ n ≥ 1, (∀ z ∈ Set.Ico x₀ (r ^ n * x₀), P z) → ∀ z ∈ Set.Ico (r ^ n * x₀) (r ^ (n + 1) * x₀), P z) →
          ∀ x ≥ x₀, P x
name: Real.induction_Ico_mul
docString:
Induction principle for intervals of real numbers: if a proposition `P` is true
on `[x₀, r * x₀)` and if `P` for `[x₀, r^n * x₀)` implies `P` for `[r^n * x₀, r^(n+1) * x₀)`,
then `P` is true for all `x ≥ x₀`.

The multiplicative indicators of closed δ-thickenings of a set tend pointwise to the
multiplicative indicator of the set, as δ tends to zero.

type:
∀ {α : Type u_1} [inst : PseudoEMetricSpace α] {β : Type u_2} [inst_1 : One β] [inst_2 : TopologicalSpace β] (f : α → β)
  (E : Set α),
  Filter.Tendsto (fun δ => Set.mulIndicator (Metric.cthickening δ E) f) (nhds 0) (nhds (Set.mulIndicator (closure E) f))
name: tendsto_mulIndicator_cthickening_mulIndicator_closure
docString:
The multiplicative indicators of closed δ-thickenings of a set tend pointwise to the
multiplicative indicator of the set, as δ tends to zero.

Technical lemma to control the addition of functions in `L^p` even for `p < 1`: Given `δ > 0`,
there exists `η` such that two functions bounded by `η` in `L^p` have a sum bounded by `δ`. One
could take `η = δ / 2` for `p ≥ 1`, but the point of the lemma is that it works also for `p < 1`.

type:
∀ {α : Type u_1} (E : Type u_2) {m0 : MeasurableSpace α} (μ : MeasureTheory.Measure α) [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E]
  (p : ENNReal) {δ : ENNReal},
  δ ≠ 0 →
    ∃ η,
      0 < η ∧
        ∀ (f g : α → E),
          MeasureTheory.AEStronglyMeasurable f μ →
            MeasureTheory.AEStronglyMeasurable g μ →
              MeasureTheory.snorm f p μ ≤ η → MeasureTheory.snorm g p μ ≤ η → MeasureTheory.snorm (f + g) p μ < δ
name: MeasureTheory.exists_Lp_half
docString:
Technical lemma to control the addition of functions in `L^p` even for `p < 1`: Given `δ > 0`,
there exists `η` such that two functions bounded by `η` in `L^p` have a sum bounded by `δ`. One
could take `η = δ / 2` for `p ≥ 1`, but the point of the lemma is that it works also for `p < 1`.

For any two elements `x`, `y` such that `0 < y`, there exists a natural number `n`
such that `x ≤ n • y`.

type: ∀ {α : Type u_2} [inst : OrderedAddCommMonoid α] [self : Archimedean α] (x : α) {y : α}, 0 < y → ∃ n, x ≤ n • y
name: Archimedean.arch
docString:
For any two elements `x`, `y` such that `0 < y`, there exists a natural number `n`
such that `x ≤ n • y`.

If `x` is a Liouville number, then for any `n`, for infinitely many denominators `b` there
exists a numerator `a` such that `x ≠ a / b` and `|x - a / b| < 1 / b ^ n`.

type: ∀ {x : ℝ}, Liouville x → ∀ (n : ℕ), ∃ᶠ (b : ℕ) in Filter.atTop, ∃ a, x ≠ ↑a / ↑b ∧ |x - ↑a / ↑b| < 1 / ↑b ^ n
name: Liouville.frequently_exists_num
docString:
If `x` is a Liouville number, then for any `n`, for infinitely many denominators `b` there
exists a numerator `a` such that `x ≠ a / b` and `|x - a / b| < 1 / b ^ n`.

Given any rational approximation `q` to the irrational real number `ξ`, there is
a good rational approximation `q'` such that `|ξ - q'| < |ξ - q|`.

type: ∀ {ξ : ℝ}, Irrational ξ → ∀ (q : ℚ), ∃ q', |ξ - ↑q'| < 1 / ↑q'.den ^ 2 ∧ |ξ - ↑q'| < |ξ - ↑q|
name: Real.exists_rat_abs_sub_lt_and_lt_of_irrational
docString:
Given any rational approximation `q` to the irrational real number `ξ`, there is
a good rational approximation `q'` such that `|ξ - q'| < |ξ - q|`.

Every x greater than or equal to 1 is between two successive
natural-number powers of every y greater than one.

type:
∀ {α : Type u_1} [inst : LinearOrderedSemiring α] [inst_1 : Archimedean α] [inst_2 : ExistsAddOfLE α] {x y : α},
  1 ≤ x → 1 < y → ∃ n, y ^ n ≤ x ∧ x < y ^ (n + 1)
name: exists_nat_pow_near
docString:
Every x greater than or equal to 1 is between two successive
natural-number powers of every y greater than one.

The modulus of (uniform) continuity for `f`, chosen so `|f x - f y| < ε/2` when `|x - y| < δ`.

type: C(↑unitInterval, ℝ) → (ε : ℝ) → 0 < ε → ℝ
name: bernsteinApproximation.δ
docString: The modulus of (uniform) continuity for `f`, chosen so `|f x - f y| < ε/2` when `|x - y| < δ`.

The infimum of `x` and `xᶜ` is at most `⊥`

type: ∀ {α : Type u} [self : BooleanAlgebra α] (x : α), x ⊓ xᶜ ≤ ⊥
name: BooleanAlgebra.inf_compl_le_bot
docString: The infimum of `x` and `xᶜ` is at most `⊥`

If a solution has `x > 1`, then `d` is positive.

type: ∀ {d : ℤ} {a : Pell.Solution₁ d}, 1 < Pell.Solution₁.x a → 0 < d
name: Pell.Solution₁.d_pos_of_one_lt_x
docString: If a solution has `x > 1`, then `d` is positive.

Nonnegativity of an element of `ℤ√d`.

type: {d : ℕ} → ℤ√↑d → Prop
name: Zsqrtd.Nonneg
docString: Nonnegativity of an element of `ℤ√d`.

Let `M` be a smooth σ-compact manifold with a metric. Let `K : ι → Set M` be a locally finite
family of closed sets, let `U : ι → Set M` be a family of open sets such that `K i ⊆ U i` for all
`i`. Then there exists a positive smooth function `δ : M → ℝ≥0` such that for any `i` and `x ∈ K i`,
we have `Metric.closedBall x (δ x) ⊆ U i`.

type:
∀ {ι : Type uι} {E : Type uE} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ℝ E] [inst_2 : FiniteDimensional ℝ E]
  {H : Type uH} [inst_3 : TopologicalSpace H] (I : ModelWithCorners ℝ E H) {M : Type u_1} [inst_4 : MetricSpace M]
  [inst_5 : ChartedSpace H M] [inst_6 : SmoothManifoldWithCorners I M] [inst_7 : SigmaCompactSpace M] {K U : ι → Set M},
  (∀ (i : ι), IsClosed (K i)) →
    (∀ (i : ι), IsOpen (U i)) →
      (∀ (i : ι), K i ⊆ U i) →
        LocallyFinite K → ∃ δ, (∀ (x : M), 0 < δ x) ∧ ∀ (i : ι), ∀ x ∈ K i, Metric.closedBall x (δ x) ⊆ U i
name: Metric.exists_smooth_forall_closedBall_subset
docString:
Let `M` be a smooth σ-compact manifold with a metric. Let `K : ι → Set M` be a locally finite
family of closed sets, let `U : ι → Set M` be a family of open sets such that `K i ⊆ U i` for all
`i`. Then there exists a positive smooth function `δ : M → ℝ≥0` such that for any `i` and `x ∈ K i`,
we have `Metric.closedBall x (δ x) ⊆ U i`.

The indicators of δ-thickenings of a set tend pointwise to the indicator of the
set, as δ>0 tends to zero.

type:
∀ {α : Type u_1} [inst : PseudoEMetricSpace α] {β : Type u_2} [inst_1 : Zero β] [inst_2 : TopologicalSpace β]
  (f : α → β) (E : Set α),
  Filter.Tendsto (fun δ => Set.indicator (Metric.thickening δ E) f) (nhdsWithin 0 (Set.Ioi 0))
    (nhds (Set.indicator (closure E) f))
name: tendsto_indicator_thickening_indicator_closure
docString:
The indicators of δ-thickenings of a set tend pointwise to the indicator of the
set, as δ>0 tends to zero.

If `ξ` is an irrational real number, then there are infinitely many good
rational approximations to `ξ`.

type: ∀ {ξ : ℝ}, Irrational ξ → Set.Infinite {q | |ξ - ↑q| < 1 / ↑q.den ^ 2}
name: Real.infinite_rat_abs_sub_lt_one_div_den_sq_of_irrational
docString:
If `ξ` is an irrational real number, then there are infinitely many good
rational approximations to `ξ`.
